animalOfTheDay.name: sloth
facts: They only come down from the trees about once a week to defecate.
Sloths have a symbiotic relationship with algae, which grows on their fur and provides camouflage.
They spend most of their lives hanging upside down in trees, even sleeping and giving birth in this position.
Sloths are the slowest mammals on Earth, moving at a top speed of about 0.24 km/h.

calendar.name: tasmanian devil
facts: Tasmanian devils are carnivorous marsupials native to Tasmania, Australia.
They are the largest carnivorous marsupial in the world.
They are known for their ferocious screeches and powerful bite.
Tasmanian devils are solitary and nocturnal scavengers.

calendar.name: termite
facts: Termites are more closely related to cockroaches than to ants.
They cultivate fungi in their nests as a food source.
Some termite mounds can be over 30 feet tall and contain millions of individuals.
Termite queens can live up to 50 years, making them among the longest-living insects.

calendar.name: tiger shark
facts: Tiger sharks are one of the few shark species that can tolerate freshwater.
They are born with distinctive stripes that fade as they mature.
They have unique, saw-like teeth that can cut through turtle shells.
Tiger sharks are called 'garbage cans of the sea' because they'll eat almost anything.

calendar.name: toad
facts: They secrete toxins from their skin to deter predators, which can be harmful if ingested.
Toads are more terrestrial than frogs and are often found far from water.
Toads have dry, warty skin, while frogs have smooth, moist skin.
Some toads, like the cane toad, have become invasive species in certain regions.

calendar.name: topi
facts: They have specialized scent glands that help them mark their territory.
They have a unique 'pronking' behavior where they leap stiff-legged when alarmed.
Topis are fast antelopes that can reach speeds of up to 50 mph.
Male topis defend small territories where females come to mate.

calendar.name: trout
facts: Trout have excellent vision and can see in color.
They can detect vibrations in the water through their lateral line system.
They are indicators of clean water and are sensitive to pollution.
Some trout species migrate between freshwater and saltwater during their life cycle.

calendar.name: sloth
facts: They only come down from the trees about once a week to defecate.
Sloths have a symbiotic relationship with algae, which grows on their fur and provides camouflage.
They spend most of their lives hanging upside down in trees, even sleeping and giving birth in this position.
Sloths are the slowest mammals on Earth, moving at a top speed of about 0.24 km/h.

randomAnimals.name: sea otter
facts: Sea otters hold hands while sleeping to prevent drifting apart.
They use rocks as tools to crack open shellfish while floating on their backs.
They play a crucial role in maintaining kelp forest ecosystems by controlling sea urchin populations.
Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal, with up to 1 million hairs per square inch.

randomAnimals.name: goblin shark
facts: Their skin is pinkish-purple because blood vessels are close to the surface.
They live in very deep waters, making them rarely encountered by humans.
Its jaws can extend forward to snatch prey, and its teeth are needle-sharp.
The goblin shark is a rare species of deep-sea shark, known for its unusual appearance, with an elongated snout and protrusible jaws.

randomAnimals.name: sea lion
facts: Sea lions can rotate their hind flippers forward to walk on land.
They are intelligent and can be trained to perform complex tasks.
They are highly social and communicate through barks, growls, and body language.
Sea lions can dive up to 900 feet and hold their breath for 10 minutes.
